questions.text: During the COVID outbreak, A 65-year-old male with warm, bounding extremities was referred to AIIMS. He presented with a 6-day history of fever not responding to medications, cough, dyspnea, diarrhea, and vomiting. CXR shows b/l lung base opacities. SpO2 = 82%, HR = 109, BP = 89/47. JVP has decreased. The patient was intubated and mechanical ventilation was initiated. He was also started with norepinephrine and vasopressin infusion, to which he responded. Saturation was deteriorating, and serum procalcitonin was found elevated. What could be the most appropriate mechanism to explain the finding?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Distributive shock History is suggestive of Distributive shock : Evidence of hypotension → Fall in SVR (Systemic vascular resistance) Evidence of raised cardiac output → Warm bounding pulses Evidence of low CVP → Low JVP History is suggestive of subtype: Septic shock Evidence of sepsis (Non responsive infectious fever with raised procalcitonin Evidence of septic shock → Hypotension requiring vasopressors Shock is the clinical condition of organ dysfunction resulting from an imbalance between cellular oxygen supply and demand . Four major type of shock Distributive Cardiogenic Hypovolemic Obstructive Distributive shock is the condition of reduced oxygen delivery where the physiologic disturbance is Reduction in SVR ( Primary disturbance) Compensatory increase in cardiac output Fall in CVP and PCWP (Pulmonary capillary wedge pressures) Sepsis : Dysregulated host response to infection resulting in life-threatening organ dysfunction. Septic shock : Sepsis when accompanied by persistent hypotension requiring vasopressor support

Highyeild:

Most common cause of distributive shock is sepsis Norepinephrine is the first choice vasopressor in septic shock Vasopressin has a role as a second agent for hypotension in septic shock

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. - Cardiogenic shock is characterized by reduced oxygen delivery related to a reduction in CO owing to a primary cardiac problem Option: C. - Obstructive shock is characterized by a reduction in oxygen delivery related to reduced CO, the etiology being an extra-cardiac processes impairing blood flow Option: D. - Hypovolemic shock encompasses disease processes that reduce CO (and oxygen delivery) via a reduction in preload

Extraedge:

In distributive shock, vasopressin deficiency may be present. Dopamine does not have a role as a first line agent in distributive shock.

questions.text: A child presented with shock at the emergency department, associated with itching, anxiety and shortness of breath. She has a history of insect bites, 2 hours ago, examination revealed low BP and increased heart rate. The senior resident on call treated the patient with IM adrenaline (1:1000). He explained to his juniors about the pathology of this shock: that it is IgE- mediated reaction which can rapidly develop after exposure to some specific substances. What could be the possible diagnosis of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anaphylactic shock The history of insect bite followed by features of allergic manifestations is suggestive of anaphylaxis. Anaphylaxis with hypotension → Anaphylactic shock. It is a subset of distributive shock. Anaphylaxis is predominantly an IgE-mediated allergic reaction that can rapidly develop after exposure to an allergen ( food, medication, or insect bite) There is a profound distributive type of shock possibly mediated through histamine release.

Highyeild:

Evidence of both venous and arterial vasodilation seen. Extravasation of up to 35% of the circulating blood volume within 10 min

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. - Septic shock - Patients with distributive shock from sepsis may present with fever and a history revealing a focal site of infection . Option: C. - Cardiac arrest – No history suggestive of cardiac problem in this child. Option: D. - It can’t be herpes, no history of fever/pain/ which might suggest viral etiology (Image below)

questions.text: A 75-year-old male presented to emergency room with chest discomfort, altered mental status, and cold, clammy skin. On examination, HR was 120 bpm, BP - 80/56, and the patient was tachypneic. The patient has a previous history of Atrial fibrillation from 3 years ago, for which he is on NOACs. The patient was asymptomatic 6 hours ago, after which he witnessed exertional chest discomfort and heavy stabbing substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm. Examination revealed increased JVP and feeble pulse (reduced cardiac output). Identify the most appropriate diagnosis.?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cardiogenic shock History of an elderly gentleman with known cardiac history of AF presenting with chest discomfort radiating to the left arm is likely MI (Myocardial infarction). Signs of cold clammy skin and feeble pulse → low cardiac output Above features with hypotension, tachycardia and raised JVP → Cardiogenic shock. Cardiogenic shock is characterized by reduced oxygen delivery related to a reduction in CO owing to a primary cardiac problem. There is usually a compensatory increase in SVR in cardiogenic shock. When the cardiac process (e.g., myocardial infarction) here affects Left ventricle (LV) → there will be elevation of the PCWP Right ventricle (RV) → CVP will be elevated. Obstructive shock - Etiology of the reduced CO is an extracardiac processes impairing blood flow

Highyeild:

Obstructive shock Processes that can impede venous return to the heart and reduce CO include: Tension pneumothorax (PTX) Cardiac tamponade Restrictive pericarditis. Processes that obstruct cardiac outflow include: Pulmonary embolism (right heart) Aortic dissection (left heart)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options B, C and D are subtypes of Obstructive shock

questions.text: A 25 year old male met with a Road Traffic Accident. He presented trauma with laceration over thigh with bleeding. He is conscious but with altered mental status, cold and clammy skin, tachypneic, HR increased, pulse was feeble, JVP decreased, blood pressure = 100/70. The attending resident immediately identified the site of bleeding and stopped it using a clamp. The patient improved after adding IV fluids. Identify the condition:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypovolemic shock History of a RTA and altered mental status along with evident site of blood loss indicate hemorrhage. Evidence of hypovolemia: Cold skin Feeble pulse Tachycardia Tachypnoea Elevated SVR Low JVP / Low CVP Improving on IV fluids Hypovolemia with hypotension → Hypovolemic shock Hypovolemic shock encompasses disease processes that reduce CO (and oxygen delivery) via a reduction in preload .

Highyeild:

Hypovolemic shock can also be seen with non hemorrhagic processes: GI illnesses causing profound emesis or diarrhea Renal losses (osmotic diuresis associated with diabetic ketoacidosis or diabetes insipidus) Skin loss (severe burns, inflammatory conditions such as Stevens-Johnson)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. - cardiogenic shock - there is no pathology of the heart which is intrinsic to it. So it can’t be the answer. Option: C. - No evidence of fat embolism with no history of fracture, no features of petechiae and no investigation of urine globules in urine. Option: D. - NOT correct as the pulse here is feeble instead of bounding and extremities are cold and clammy instead of warm as in distributive shock.

questions.text: A 25 year old male met with a RTA presented to a trauma center with c/o breathlessness. He has no visible bleeds, BP = 80/50. Auscultation revealed no air entry to the right side of the chest. Which of the following types of shock can this patient present with?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Obstructive shock History of RTA in above scenario, presenting with Hypotension No visible hemorrhage Sign of no air entry on right → Indicative of an extra cardiac cause likely tension pneumothorax which is impeding venous return leading to hypotension. Obstructive shock - Characterized by Reduction in oxygen delivery related to reduced CO (Cardiac output) Etiology of the reduced CO is an extra-cardiac process impairing blood flow. Processes that can impede venous return to the heart and reduce CO include: Tension pneumothorax (PTX) Cardiac tamponade Restrictive pericarditis. Processes that obstruct cardiac outflow include: Pulmonary embolism (right heart) Aortic dissection (left heart

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. - No visible bleed and presence of absent air entry with breathlessness rules out hypovolemia Option: B. - No evidence of infection or allergic manifestations or shift in blood or fluids in compartments. Option: D. - Finding of absent air entry rules out Pulmonary embolism.
